column50: optimized synthetic path to fentanyl (4) is outlined in Fig. 4 and it begins with the alkylation of commercially available 4-piperidone monohydrate hydrochloride 12 with 2-(bromoethyl)benzene in the presence of cesium carbonate to furnish alkylated piperidone 13 in 88% yield. Reductive amination with aniline of 13 mediated by sodium triacetoxyborohydride in the presence of acetic acid yielded the 4-piperidineamine precursor 14 in excellent yield (91%). Lastly
column51: piperidineamine 14 was acylated using propionyl chloride in the presence of Hunigâ€™s base to provide fentanyl (4) in 95% yield. Likewise
column52: piperidineamine 14 was treated with acetic anhydride in the presence of Hunigâ€™s base to provide acetylfentanyl (9) in 98% yield. Conversion of 4 and 9 into their hydrochloride and citrate salts proceeded smoothly in nearly quantitative yields (Fig. 3). The synthesis of the thiofentanyl analogs was accomplished in a similar fashion as shown in Fig. 5. Thus
column53: 4-piperidone monohydrate hydrochloride 12 was alkylated with 2-(thiophen-2-yl)ethyl methanesulfonate (19) [32] in the presence of cesium carbonate to give N-[2-(2-thienyl)ethyl]-4-piperidinone (20) in 90% yield. Reductive amination with aniline of 20 with sodium triacetoxyborohydride and acetic acid yielded the 4-piperidineamine precursor 21 in 87% yield. Lastly
column54: piperidineamine 21 was acylated using propionyl chloride to provide thiofentanyl (10) in 97% yield. Likewise
column55: piperidineamine 21 was treated with acetic anhydride in the presence of Hunigâ€™s base to provide acetylthiofentanyl (11) in 94% yield. As before
column56: conversion of 10 and 11 to their respective hydrochloride and citric acid salts was accomplished smoothly in nearly quantitative yields (Fig. 3).

column1: Due to the low-yielding characteristics of our initial attempts
column2: we decided to explore optimization studies for the synthesis of fentanyl (4) and then apply these to the syntheses of the analogs. Several conditions for each one of the steps composing the overall sequence were considered and evaluated (Table 1). We deduced that optimal conditions discovered for the synthesis of 4 could be directly translated to the syntheses of fentanyls 9â€“11 as they all share a common synthetic pathway. Thus

column4: entries 1 and 2). This was also observed during the synthesis of the thiofentanyl precursor (20) that made use of the mesylate (19) as the alkylating species where the yield markedly increased from 62 to 83% (Table 1
column5: entries 3 and 4). For the reductive amination (RA) step
column6: the need for an equimolar amount of acetic acid was noted as this resulted in the efficient conversion of ketone 13 into the piperidineamine precursor 14 in the presence of sodium triacetoxyborohydride (Table 1
column7: entry 5) [33]
column8: [34]. Carrying out the reductive amination under the same conditions but switching the hydride source to either sodium cyanoborohydride or sodium borohydride resulted in significant loss of yield at room temperature (Table 1

column11: entries 8 and 9). Lastly

column64: optimized synthetic path to fentanyl (4) is outlined in Fig. 4 and it begins with the alkylation of commercially available 4-piperidone monohydrate hydrochloride 12 with 2-(bromoethyl)benzene in the presence of cesium carbonate to furnish alkylated piperidone 13 in 88% yield. Reductive amination with aniline of 13 mediated by sodium triacetoxyborohydride in the presence of acetic acid yielded the 4-piperidineamine precursor 14 in excellent yield (91%). Lastly
column65: piperidineamine 14 was acylated using propionyl chloride in the presence of Hunigâ€™s base to provide fentanyl (4) in 95% yield. Likewise
column66: piperidineamine 14 was treated with acetic anhydride in the presence of Hunigâ€™s base to provide acetylfentanyl (9) in 98% yield. Conversion of 4 and 9 into their hydrochloride and citrate salts proceeded smoothly in nearly quantitative yields (Fig. 3). The synthesis of the thiofentanyl analogs was accomplished in a similar fashion as shown in Fig. 5. Thus

column1: The conversion of codeine to morphine

The 0-demethylation of codeine to yield morphine (Fig. 2) has been reported using a variety of reagents including sodium propylmercaptide in dimethylformamide [l] and boron tribromide in chloroform [2]. These methods require a considerable measure of chemical expertise and suitable laboratory equipment. The homebake laboratories have employed a very simple method based on the use of pyridine hydrochloride. This reagent was introduced to opiate chemistry by Rapoport and Bonner [3] and applied to the conversion of codeine to morphine by Rapoport et al. [4]. Rapoport and Bonner carried out the reaction under nitrogen at a temperature of 220Â°C. Morphine is prone to decomposition or oxidation reactions at elevated temperatures and the nitrogen atmosphere prevents or reduces these. It also limits the access of moisture which reduces the yield.
The acetylation of morphine to form heroin
In the acetylation of morphine to yield heroin (diacetylmorphine) the phenolic_OH group on the S-carbon is the first to react to give
column2: as an intermediate
column3: 3-0-monoacetylmorphine
column4: which is further acetylated to heroin. Similarly
column5: when heroin is deacetylated
column6: either by hydrolysis or enzymatically
column7: the more reactive 3-acetyl group tends to be removed first to yield 6-0- monoacetylmorphine as the predominant intermediate
column8: although low levels of 3-0-monoacetylmorphine may also be formed under these conditions (Fig. 3) [5].

column2: sulfur mustard was formerly made using the Levenstein process in which ethylene was reacted with sulphur monochloride at 30â€“ 35 Â°C. Sulfur mustard produced by this process contains 62â€“64% distilled sulfur mustard (or HD) (Munro et al. 1999). This process produces a complex mixture that includes constituents that are more toxic than sulfur mustard itself (Rosenblatt et al. 1975). The most recent process used in the United States involved the formation of bis-(2-hydroxyethyl)-thioether from ethylene oxide and hydrogen sulfide; this was then reacted with hydrochloric acid to form sulfur mustard (Franke 1967; IARC 1975; Rosenblatt et al. 1975). Sulfur mustard produced by this process contains 89% HD (Munro et al. 1999).

The nitro group that is ortho to the amino group of intermediate II was then selectively reduced using aqueous ammonium sulfide (or a suitable equivalent) in refluxing ethanol to afford III (Zinin reduction).51 Condensation of III with an appropriately substituted phenylacetic acid derivative (such as in the presence of N-ethoxycarbonyl-2-ethoxy-1

column1: The conversion of codeine to morphine

The 0-demethylation of codeine to yield morphine (Fig. 2) has been reported using a variety of reagents including sodium propylmercaptide in dimethylformamide [l] and boron tribromide in chloroform [2]. These methods require a considerable measure of chemical expertise and suitable laboratory equipment. The homebake laboratories have employed a very simple method based on the use of pyridine hydrochloride. This reagent was introduced to opiate chemistry by Rapoport and Bonner [3] and applied to the conversion of codeine to morphine by Rapoport et al. [4]. Rapoport and Bonner carried out the reaction under nitrogen at a temperature of 220Â°C. Morphine is prone to decomposition or oxidation reactions at elevated temperatures and the nitrogen atmosphere prevents or reduces these. It also limits the access of moisture which reduces the yield.
The acetylation of morphine to form heroin
In the acetylation of morphine to yield heroin (diacetylmorphine) the phenolic_OH group on the S-carbon is the first to react to give
column2: as an intermediate
column3: 3-0-monoacetylmorphine
column4: which is further acetylated to heroin. Similarly
column5: when heroin is deacetylated
column6: either by hydrolysis or enzymatically
column7: the more reactive 3-acetyl group tends to be removed first to yield 6-0- monoacetylmorphine as the predominant intermediate
column8: although low levels of 3-0-monoacetylmorphine may also be formed under these conditions (Fig. 3) [5].

column2: sulfur mustard was formerly made using the Levenstein process in which ethylene was reacted with sulphur monochloride at 30â€“ 35 Â°C. Sulfur mustard produced by this process contains 62â€“64% distilled sulfur mustard (or HD) (Munro et al. 1999). This process produces a complex mixture that includes constituents that are more toxic than sulfur mustard itself (Rosenblatt et al. 1975). The most recent process used in the United States involved the formation of bis-(2-hydroxyethyl)-thioether from ethylene oxide and hydrogen sulfide; this was then reacted with hydrochloric acid to form sulfur mustard (Franke 1967; IARC 1975; Rosenblatt et al. 1975). Sulfur mustard produced by this process contains 89% HD (Munro et al. 1999).

column2: also known as the Amritsar massacre
column3: took place on 13 April 1919. A large
column4: peaceful crowd had gathered at the Jallianwala Bagh in Amritsar
column5: Punjab
column6: British India
column7: during annual Baishakhi fair
column8: to protest against the Rowlatt Act and the arrest of pro-independence activists Saifuddin Kitchlu and Satyapal. In response to the public gathering

column10: surrounded the people with his Gurkha
column11: and Sikh infantry regiments of the British Indian Army.[7] The Jallianwala Bagh could only be exited on one side
column12: as its other three sides were enclosed by buildings. After blocking the exit with his troops
column13: he ordered them to shoot at the crowd
column14: continuing to fire even as the protestors tried to flee. The troops kept on firing until their ammunition was exhausted.[8] Estimates of those killed vary from 379 to 1
column15: 500 or more people[1] and over 1
column16: 200 other people were injured of whom 192 were seriously injured.[9][10] Britain has never formally apologised for the massacre but expressed ""deep regret"" in 2019.

column1: The massacre caused a re-evaluation by the British Army of its military role against civilians to ""minimal force whenever possible""
column2: although later British actions during the Mau Mau rebellion in the Kenya Colony have led historian Huw Bennett to comment that the new policy could sometimes be put aside.[11] The army was retrained and developed less violent tactics for crowd control.[12] The level of casual brutality
column3: and lack of any accountability
column4: stunned the entire nation
column5: [13] resulting in a wrenching loss of faith of the general Indian public in the intentions of the United Kingdom.[14] The attack was condemned by the Secretary of State for War
column6: Winston Churchill
column7: as ""unutterably monstrous""
column8: and in the UK House of Commons debate on 8 July 1920 Members of Parliament voted 247 to 37 against Dyer. The ineffective inquiry
column9: together with the initial accolades for Dyer
column10: fuelled great widespread anger against the British among the Indian populace
column11: leading to the non-cooperation movement of 1920â€“22.[15] Some historians consider the episode a decisive step towards the end of British rule in India.[16][17]
